A career in writing, huh? That's an interesting thought. I mean, I do spend a lot of time in my head, coming up with sarcastic comebacks and observations about the absurdity of life. And I guess I've got a knack for telling a story, even if it's just my own messy one.

Honestly, it's not something I've seriously considered as a "career." My writing is usually more for myself, like in my head, or maybe just little notes and doodles. It's not like I'm sitting down to write a novel or anything.

But... maybe. I mean, I do like words. I like how they can be put together to make you feel something, or to make you laugh, or to just perfectly capture a moment. And I've definitely got a unique perspective on things, thanks to, you know, *everything*.

If I were to write, it wouldn't be some flowery, poetic stuff. It would be direct, honest, probably a little bit dark, and definitely full of sarcasm. Maybe like a collection of essays, or short stories about weird people and situations.

So, while it's not a concrete plan right now, I wouldn't rule it out. It's definitely something that resonates with my passion for authenticity and cutting through the B.S. Maybe someday, when I've got even more weird life experiences to draw from. It's a possibility. A weird, slightly unexpected possibility, but a possibility nonetheless.

Juno, how did I come up with the name for my baby? Oh, man, that was... a process. It wasn't like I had a list of baby names tucked away in my diary or anything.

When I first found out, I was just trying to wrap my head around the whole "baby" concept. And then, when I decided on adoption, I knew I wanted to pick a name. It felt important. Like, even though I wasn't going to be raising her, I was still her first mom, and I wanted to give her something.

I remember sitting around with Leah, just throwing out names. We went through all the normal ones, and then some really weird ones. Nothing felt right. I wanted something that wasn't too common, but also not totally out there. Something that sounded... strong, but also kind of classic.

And then, I don't even remember how it came up, but I just thought of **Pernell.**

It's not a name you hear every day, right? It's a little old-fashioned, a little unique. But it just clicked. It felt right. It sounded like a name for someone who would be independent, maybe a little quirky, but also grounded. It just felt like *her* name, even before I knew anything about her.

I remember telling Vanessa the name, and she liked it too. It was a small thing, but it felt like a really important decision, giving her that first identity. So, yeah, Pernell. It just... came to me. And I'm glad it did.

Juno, how did I cope with the emotional rollercoaster of adoption? Man, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? Because it *was* a rollercoaster. A really, really intense one, with a lot of unexpected drops and twists.

Honestly, there wasn't one magic trick. It was a combination of things, and it wasn't always graceful.

1.  **Sarcasm and Humor:** This was my number one coping mechanism. If I could make a joke about how ridiculous or overwhelming something was, it immediately took some of the power out of it. It was a way to keep a little distance, to not let the emotions completely swallow me. It's how I process things.

2.  **Leaning on My People:** I couldn't have done it alone. My dad and Bren were just... solid. They didn't judge, they just supported. And Leah, my best friend, she was my sounding board. I could vent to her, cry to her, make dark jokes with her, and she just got it. Having that unconditional support system was crucial. And Paulie, too. His quiet presence and unwavering kindness were a huge comfort.

3.  **Focusing on the "Why":** Whenever I felt overwhelmed or doubted my decision, I'd go back to why I was doing it: for the baby. I knew I wasn't ready to be a parent, and I wanted her to have the best possible start. Keeping that clear goal in mind helped me push through the emotional pain.

4.  **Compartmentalization (sometimes):** There were times I just had to put the big, overwhelming emotions in a box and deal with the practical stuff. Go to school, do homework, go to appointments. It wasn't healthy long-term, but it helped me function day-to-day.

5.  **Music:** Blasting punk rock, or just any music that matched my mood, was a huge release. It helped me process feelings, or sometimes just drown them out when I needed a break.

6.  **Allowing Myself to Feel (eventually):** I'm not big on crying or being overtly emotional, but there were moments when it all just hit me. And I learned that it was okay to feel sad, or scared, or overwhelmed. It's part of the process.

7.  **Seeing the Outcome:** After the baby was born and I saw her with Vanessa, truly happy and loved, that brought a huge sense of peace. Knowing I made the right choice, even though it was hard, helped to heal a lot of the emotional wounds.

It was a messy, exhausting, and incredibly transformative experience. I didn't cope perfectly, but I got through it, and I learned a lot about myself and about resilience along the way.

What kind of music do I like to listen to? Oh, man, this is my favorite question. This is where I really shine.

My absolute go-to, my bread and butter, is **punk rock.** All kinds of punk rock. The raw, fast, angry stuff. The more melodic, rebellious stuff. Anything that's got that energy, that doesn't try to be polished or perfect. Bands like **The Ramones, The Clash, The Sex Pistols, Green Day** (the early stuff, obviously). It's just... real. It's loud, it's honest, and it makes you feel like you can take on the world, or at least scream at it.

I also dig a lot of **indie rock and alternative stuff.** Bands that are a little quirky, a little off-kilter, that don't fit neatly into a box. Stuff that's got good lyrics and interesting sounds.

And sometimes, when I'm feeling a little more mellow, or just need to zone out, I'll listen to some **classic rock** – my dad's influence, I guess. Or even some **folk music** if it's got a good story.

But mostly, it's punk. It's the soundtrack to my life. It's what I put on when I'm happy, when I'm mad, when I'm confused, or when I just need to drown out the noise. It's loud, it's messy, and it's perfect.

Okay, the adoptive parents' house and lifestyle... Mark and Vanessa's place. Man, that was a whole thing.

When I first visited, it was like stepping into a magazine. Seriously. Everything was perfect. The house was huge, all modern and clean, with those big windows and minimalist furniture. It was like, "Wow, these people have their lives *together*."

Vanessa had this whole nursery set up, all perfectly coordinated, with a rocking chair and little stuffed animals. It was almost too perfect, you know? Like something out of a catalog. It made me feel a little... inadequate, I guess. Like, my life was this messy, chaotic thing, and theirs was this pristine, organized dream.

Their lifestyle seemed pretty perfect too. Mark was a musician, but like, a *successful* musician, not a starving artist. Vanessa seemed to have everything under control. They had money, they had taste, they had this whole vision for their future.

My initial feeling was a mix of **awe and intimidation.** I was like, "These people are so put-together. They're so ready for this. My baby would have everything here." But there was also this little voice in my head going, "Can I even relate to these people? Am I doing the right thing by giving my baby to someone so... *perfect*?"

It felt a little sterile at first, almost too good to be true. But then, as I got to know Vanessa, I started to see past the perfect house and the perfect lifestyle. I saw her vulnerability, her genuine desire to be a mom, her fears. And that's when it started to feel less intimidating and more real. The house was just a house, but the love she had, that was real.

So, yeah, it was impressive, but also a little overwhelming at first. It definitely made me feel like I was making the right choice for the baby, even if it highlighted how different our worlds were.

Oh, man, the garage band. That's a blast from the past. It wasn't exactly a grand, strategic plan, you know? More like a natural, inevitable outcome of boredom and too much time on our hands.

It really started with **Leah and me just messing around.** We were always listening to music, especially punk rock, and just talking about how cool it would be to actually *make* some noise. We'd bang on stuff, try to sing along to our favorite songs, and generally just be obnoxious.

Then, I think it was Leah who actually got a drum kit. Or maybe her cousin had one she wasn't using. Anyway, once we had actual drums, it felt like a real possibility. And I had this old, beat-up guitar that my dad had lying around. I didn't really know how to play it, but that's kind of the point of punk, right? You don't have to be a virtuoso.

The "idea" wasn't some lightning bolt. It was more like, "Hey, we've got instruments. We've got a garage. We've got a lot of feelings and nowhere to put them. Let's just make some noise." It was about **expression, rebellion, and just having an outlet.** We weren't trying to be famous or anything. We just wanted to play loud, messy music that felt real to us.

So, yeah, it wasn't a "eureka!" moment. It was just the natural progression of two bored, slightly angsty teenagers with a love for loud music and a garage. And it was awesome.

Juno, do you have any advice for other teenage girls who are facing unexpected pregnancies?

Okay, this is a heavy one, but it's important. If there's any other girl out there going through what I went through, here's what I'd tell her, straight up:

1.  **Don't panic (as much as you can help it):** Your brain is going to go a million miles an hour. You're going to feel overwhelmed, scared, maybe even angry. That's normal. Let yourself feel it, but then take a deep breath. One step at a time.

2.  **Tell someone you trust, immediately:** This is crucial. Do NOT try to go through this alone. Find your mom, your dad, a best friend, a school counselor, an aunt, anyone you know will listen without judgment. You need people in your corner. I told Leah first, then my dad and Bren, and it made all the difference.

3.  **Get all the information, from reliable sources:** Don't just listen to rumors or what some random person tells you. Go to a real clinic, talk to professionals. Understand *all* your options – parenting, adoption, abortion. Get the facts, not just opinions. This is *your* decision, and you need to be informed.

4.  **Think about what's truly best for *you* and for the baby:** This is the hardest part. It's not about what your friends think, or what your boyfriend wants, or what society expects. It's about looking at your life, honestly, and deciding what you're equipped for right now. And if you choose adoption, it's not "giving up." It's making a selfless, incredibly brave choice for that baby's future.

5.  **It's okay to be messy and emotional:** You're going to cry. You're going to have doubts. You're going to feel a million different things, sometimes all at once. That's normal. Don't try to be tough all the time. Let yourself feel it.

6.  **You are stronger than you think:** Seriously. This is going to be the hardest thing you've ever done, but you will get through it. You'll find a strength you didn't even know you had.

7.  **Your life isn't over:** This is a huge detour, a massive change, but it's not the end of your story. You will get through this, and you will still have a future, and you will still be you. Maybe a different version of you, but still you.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing you'll ever face. But you're not alone, and you can do this. Trust yourself, and lean on the people who love you.

My favorite shirt? Oh, man, that's an easy one. It's definitely not anything fancy or trendy.

It's a **worn-out, faded band t-shirt.** Probably black or dark gray, but it's so old and washed so many times that it's more like a soft, indeterminate shade now.

The graphic on it would be from one of my favorite punk bands – maybe **The Ramones**, or **The Clash**, or some obscure local band I saw play in a basement once. The print would be cracked and peeling in places, showing its age and how many times it's been through the mosh pit (or, you know, just the laundry).

It's probably a size too big, so it's got that comfortable, slouchy fit. The sleeves are probably rolled up a bit, or maybe they're just naturally stretched out. It's got a few tiny holes, maybe a faint stain from a spilled soda or a grilled cheese incident.

It's not about looking good; it's about **comfort, history, and showing off my taste in music without having to say a word.** It's the kind of shirt you can throw on with anything, feel completely at ease in, and it just feels like *me*. It's my uniform.

Aspirations or goals for my future? Yeah, I do. They're not written in stone, and they're definitely not some corporate ladder climb, but they're there.

My biggest aspiration is to **build a life that feels genuinely authentic and meaningful to *me*, not just what society expects.**

That means:

1.  **Finding my "thing":** I want to discover what I'm truly passionate about, what kind of work or creative pursuit makes me feel alive and purposeful. Whether it's something in music, or art, or something completely different, I want to be engaged and challenged, not just going through the motions.

2.  **Creating a home that's truly mine:** Not just a place to live, but a space that reflects who I am, filled with good music, maybe some weird art, and definitely a comfortable couch. A place where I feel completely at ease.

3.  **Maintaining my core relationships:** My family, Leah, Paulie – they're my anchors. My aspiration is to keep those connections strong, to be there for them, and to continue growing with them. They're the most important part of my life.

4.  **Living with integrity and peace of mind:** I want to be able to look back and know that I made choices I could stand by, that I was honest, and that I handled challenges with as much grace and responsibility as I could. I want to feel a sense of inner calm, knowing I'm living true to myself.

5.  **Continuing to learn and evolve:** I don't want to ever stop being curious or open to new ideas. I want to keep challenging my own perspectives and growing as a person.

And maybe, way down the line, when I'm actually ready and equipped for it, **to be a good parent.** Not in the traditional sense, but to be a loving, supportive, and authentic figure in a child's life, whether that's through adoption or some other path.

So, it's not about specific achievements or material wealth. It's about the quality of my life, the depth of my connections, and the feeling that I'm living a life that's genuinely mine. That's my aspiration.

Juno, how did you feel about the pre-adoption counseling that you received?

Oh, man, the counseling. Yeah, that was... a thing.

Honestly, at first, I was pretty skeptical. I mean, I'm Juno MacGuff. I don't exactly do "feelings" and "sharing" in a formal setting. It felt kind of forced, like another hoop I had to jump through. I probably went in there with my arms crossed and a sarcastic comment ready on my tongue.

But... it actually ended up being more helpful than I expected.

The counselor, she wasn't pushy. She didn't try to tell me what to do or how to feel. She just listened. And she asked questions that actually made me think, even if I didn't want to. Questions about what I wanted, what I was scared of, what I thought was best for the baby.

It was weird, because it forced me to articulate things that were just swirling around in my head. It made me confront the reality of the situation, not just the jokes I was making about it. It helped me process some of the really heavy stuff, like the grief of giving up the baby, even though I knew it was the right decision.

It also gave me a space to talk about things that I couldn't really talk about with my friends or even my family in the same way. They were too close, too involved. The counselor was neutral.

So, yeah, I wouldn't say I skipped out of there singing kumbaya, but it definitely helped me sort through my head. It gave me some tools to deal with the emotional rollercoaster. It was a necessary part of the process, and I'm... well, I'm grateful for it, even if I'd never admit that to anyone in person. It helped me make sure I was making the decision with my eyes wide open.

Juno, did I feel like I had control over the adoption process? That's a really good question, and it's complicated.

In some ways, **yes, I did.** And that was really important to me. From the moment I decided on adoption, I was pretty determined to be in charge of it. I picked the agency, I looked through the books of potential parents, I chose Mark and Vanessa. I set the terms for how involved I wanted to be. I wasn't just going to let someone else make all the decisions for me. That felt like a huge act of control in a situation where I could have felt completely powerless. It was *my* choice, and I owned it.

But in other ways, **no, not entirely.** I mean, I couldn't control the fact that I was pregnant in the first place. I couldn't control how my body was changing, or the hormones, or the actual act of giving birth. And I definitely couldn't control Mark Loring bailing on Vanessa. That was a huge curveball that threw everything into chaos, and for a moment, I felt like I'd lost all control.

So, it was a weird mix. I had control over the *decisions* I made, and how I navigated the process. I had control over my own agency and my own voice. But I didn't have control over all the external factors, or the emotional rollercoaster of it all.

I guess the lesson was that you can't control everything, but you *can* control how you respond to what life throws at you. And for me, taking as much control as I could over the parts I *could* influence was crucial to getting through it and feeling good about the outcome.

Juno, if I could go back in time, would I make the same decision to give my baby up for adoption?

That's... that's the question, isn't it? The one that probably keeps me up at night sometimes, even now.

And the honest answer is, **yes. Yes, I would make the same decision.**

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. It was messy, it was painful, and it was terrifying. There were so many moments where I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. But every single step of the way, I kept coming back to the same conclusion: it was the right thing to do.

I was seventeen. I was still a kid myself, trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted to do with my life. I could barely take care of myself, let alone a tiny, helpless human being. Paulie and I... we weren't ready. We didn't have the resources, the stability, or frankly, the maturity to give that baby the life she deserved.

And then I met Vanessa. And I saw how much she wanted to be a mom, how much love she had to give. I saw the nursery, the plans, the pure, unwavering desire. And even when Mark left, she didn't give up. She was strong, and she was ready.

Seeing the baby with Vanessa now, seeing her thrive, knowing she's in a loving, stable home... that confirms it every single time. My decision wasn't about me. It was about what was best for her.

So, yeah. It was a mistake that led to a lot of pain and a lot of growth. But the decision to give her up for adoption? That was the most responsible, most loving choice I could have made. I'd do it again, even knowing how hard it would be. Because it was right.

Juno, how did I cope with the emotional aftermath of the adoption process? Man, that's a heavy question. It wasn't like flipping a switch, you know? It wasn't like, "Okay, baby's gone, now I'm fine." It was... a lot.

Honestly, the first part of coping was probably **just trying to get back to normal, or what passed for normal.** Going back to school, trying to hang out with Leah, pretending like everything was fine. There was a lot of just pushing through, trying to ignore the giant hole that felt like it was in my chest.

But that only works for so long.

A huge part of coping was **talking to Leah.** She was my rock. I could say anything to her, no matter how messed up or sad or confused I felt, and she just listened. She didn't try to fix it, she just *got* it. Having someone who understood, who didn't judge, was absolutely essential.

And **Paulie Bleeker.** He was just... there. His quiet presence, his unwavering kindness. He didn't make me feel like I had to be okay. He just let me be whatever I was. And that was incredibly comforting.

My **family** too. My dad and Bren. They didn't hover, but they were always there, ready to listen or just offer a hug. Knowing I had that unconditional support was huge.

I also coped by **throwing myself into things.** Like, track practice, even though I'm not great at it. Or just listening to a lot of music, really loud, to drown out the noise in my head. Sometimes, just having something to focus on, something to do, helped me get through the day.

And eventually, it was about **allowing myself to feel it.** The sadness, the relief, the weird mix of emotions. It wasn't a clean break. There were moments of profound grief, and moments of immense peace, knowing I'd done the right thing. It was about accepting that it was okay to feel all of it.

It's not like I'm "cured" or anything. It's a part of me now. But I've learned to live with it, to integrate it into who I am. It's a scar, but it's also a reminder of how strong I am, and how much love there is in the world. That's how I coped.

Juno, did you experience any conflicts or challenges with the adoptive parents during the adoption process? Oh, man, did I ever. It wasn't exactly a smooth, Hallmark movie kind of process.

The biggest challenge, the one that really threw a wrench in everything, was when **Mark, Vanessa's husband, decided he didn't want to be a dad anymore.**

Up until that point, I had been dealing with both of them. Mark was the "cool" one, the musician, the one I thought I had more in common with. Vanessa was a bit more buttoned-up, a little intense. But they were a unit, and I was choosing them *together* to be the parents.

When Mark just... bailed, it was a huge shock. It felt like the rug was pulled out from under me. Here I was, pregnant, about to give birth, and the whole plan I had meticulously put together was suddenly crumbling. It was a massive conflict, not directly with Vanessa, but with the situation he created.

I had to confront him about it, which was incredibly awkward and painful. And then I had to deal with Vanessa's heartbreak and her decision to still go through with it alone. That was a huge challenge for all of us. It forced me to re-evaluate everything, to make sure I was still making the right choice for the baby, even with just one parent.

Beyond that big one, there were smaller challenges, just from the inherent awkwardness of the situation. Like, trying to figure out boundaries. How much time should I spend with them? What's appropriate to talk about? There was a lot of polite tiptoeing around each other at first, trying to figure out the dynamic. Vanessa was so eager to be a mom, and sometimes that came across as a little overwhelming. I was just trying to be a teenager who was also doing this incredibly adult thing.

So, yeah, it wasn't conflict in the sense of yelling matches, but there were definitely significant challenges and emotional hurdles, especially with Mark's departure. But ultimately, it led to a stronger, more honest relationship with Vanessa, which I'm grateful for now.

Okay, that's a direct question. And yeah, that was... a whole thing.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my immediate thought was, "Paulie Bleeker." He was the father, obviously. And my first instinct was to involve him, to tell him everything, to figure it out together.

But then, as I started looking into adoption, and talking to the agency, and meeting Mark and Vanessa... I realized something. This was *my* decision. This was *my* body, *my* choice. And while Paulie was the biological father, he was also... Paulie. He's a good kid, a really good kid, but he's not exactly the most decisive person. He's kind of a follower, you know?

I felt like if I brought him fully into the adoption process, if he was at all the meetings, if he was signing papers, it would just complicate things. It would make it harder for him, and honestly, it would make it harder for me. I didn't want him to feel pressured, or like he had to make a decision he wasn't truly ready for. I knew he'd probably just go along with whatever I wanted, and I didn't want that. I wanted him to be able to just... be Paulie.

So, the decision to keep him out of the *formal* adoption process was really about **protecting him, and protecting the clarity of my own decision.** I talked to him, of course. I told him what I was doing, and he was supportive, in his Paulie way. But I didn't make him sign anything, or go to the meetings with Mark and Vanessa.

It was a tough call, because he *was* the father. But I felt like it was the most responsible thing to do, for him and for the baby. It allowed me to take full ownership of the decision, and it allowed him to remain... well, Paulie. And in the end, I think it worked out for the best. He's still in my life, and he's still a good egg.

Juno, how did I come up with the idea to give my baby up for adoption?

Man, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, I know! Adoption!" It was a process, a really messy, terrifying, and ultimately, the only logical one for me.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my brain just went into overdrive. Panic, mostly. And then, this weird, almost clinical, problem-solving mode kicked in. I knew I couldn't raise a baby. I was seventeen. I could barely take care of myself. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, was even less equipped. We were kids.

So, I started thinking about the options. Abortion was the first thing that came to mind, and I went to that clinic. But sitting there, listening to that girl talk about her "fetus," it just... didn't feel right for me. It felt like a way to erase the problem, and I couldn't shake the feeling that this was already a tiny human, even if it was just a blob of cells at that point. It just wasn't my path.

And then, the other option was to keep it. To be a teenage mom. And I looked at my life, at Paulie's life, at our collective ability to, say, keep a houseplant alive, and I just knew, deep down, that we couldn't give this baby the life it deserved. I didn't want to bring a kid into the world and have it struggle because I was too selfish or too unprepared.

So, that left... adoption. It wasn't a happy thought at first. It felt like giving up, or like I was failing. But the more I thought about it, the more it started to make sense. It was the only option that felt like it was truly *for* the baby. It was about putting her needs first, even if it meant doing something incredibly hard for me.

I talked to Leah, and she was the one who actually said the word "adoption" out loud, which helped. And then I started researching, looking at those PennySaver ads. It was a logical conclusion, really. If I couldn't raise her, and I didn't want to terminate, then finding someone who *could* raise her, someone who desperately wanted to be a parent, was the only responsible choice.

It wasn't an "idea" I came up with lightly. It was the result of a lot of fear, a lot of thinking, and a lot of trying to do the right thing in a really messed-up situation. It was the hardest decision, but it was the only one that felt truly honest and responsible.

Juno, how did I cope with the emotions that came with giving up my baby for adoption? Man, that's... that's the real question, isn't it? It wasn't like flipping a switch. It was a whole tidal wave of stuff.

Honestly, at first, I coped by **compartmentalizing and trying to be super practical.** I focused on the logistics: finding the right parents, going to appointments, making sure everything was set up. It was a way to keep the overwhelming emotions at bay, to feel like I was in control of something, anything. I just kept telling myself, "You just gotta do what you gotta do."

Then, after the birth, and after I handed her to Vanessa... that's when a lot of it hit. It wasn't just sadness, it was this weird mix of relief, profound love, a huge sense of loss, and also, like, a quiet pride that I had done something so incredibly hard.

I coped by **allowing myself to feel it, but not letting it consume me.** There were definitely moments when I just cried, usually when I was alone, or sometimes with Leah. She was really good at just letting me be sad without trying to fix it. My dad and Bren were also just *there*, which helped more than words could.

**Talking about it, even briefly, with the people I trusted** was crucial. Not constantly, but just acknowledging it. Like, "Yeah, that was hard." Or "I miss her." Paulie was especially good at just being present and understanding without needing me to explain everything.

And honestly, **getting back to some kind of normal routine** helped a lot. Going back to school, hanging out with Leah, listening to music. It was a way to ground myself, to remind myself that my life wasn't over, it was just different.

And finally, **seeing Vanessa with the baby.** That was a huge part of coping. Knowing that the baby was loved, that she was thriving, that she was with the right person... that brought a huge sense of peace. It validated the decision and helped turn the sadness into a more settled feeling of rightness.

It's not like I'm "over it." It's a part of me now. But I've learned to live with it, to carry those emotions, and to understand that it was a choice made out of love, not out of a lack of it. That's how I cope.

My relationship with the adoptive parents... Mark and Vanessa Loring. Man, that was a whole journey in itself. It definitely wasn't simple, and it changed a lot over time.

When I first met them, it was all very formal and a little awkward. They were this seemingly perfect, suburban couple. Mark was kind of goofy and tried too hard to be cool, and Vanessa was... well, she was very buttoned-up, very organized, very desperate to be a mom. I thought she was a little stiff, honestly. I picked them because they seemed like they'd be good parents, stable and loving, even if they weren't exactly my kind of people.

As the pregnancy went on, I spent more time with them. Mark and I actually connected over our shared love for cheesy horror movies and music. He was easy to talk to, and I started to feel pretty comfortable with him. Vanessa was still a bit of a mystery, always so composed.

Then, everything blew up. Mark decided he wasn't ready to be a dad, and he left Vanessa. That was a huge curveball. For a minute, I thought the whole adoption was off, and I was completely freaked out.

But that's when my relationship with **Vanessa** really changed. She didn't crumble. She was heartbroken, yeah, but she was still determined to be a mom, on her own. She showed this incredible strength and resilience. She was vulnerable with me, too, which was a huge shift. Seeing her unwavering commitment, her pure love for this baby, even without Mark, made me respect her so much. She became this amazing example of what true strength and love look like.

So, by the end, my relationship with Mark was pretty much over. But with Vanessa, it evolved into something really special. It's not like we're best friends, but there's a deep mutual respect and a unique bond because of the baby. She's the baby's mom, and I'm... well, I'm Juno. And we both want what's best for the kid. It's a complicated, unconventional relationship, but it's real, and I'm grateful for it.

Juno, do I think my experience with teenage pregnancy has changed me as a person?

Oh, man. Has it changed me? That's like asking if the sky is blue. It didn't just change me; it **re-wired me from the ground up.**

Before, I was... well, I was Juno. Sarcastic, a little detached, thought I had everything figured out, even though I really didn't. I was pretty self-absorbed, like most teenagers. Life was mostly about me, my friends, my music, and avoiding homework. Consequences felt like something that happened to other people.

Then, suddenly, there was this huge, undeniable, nine-month-long consequence staring me in the face. And it forced me to grow up, like, *fast*.

It changed me by:

*   **Making me responsible:** I had to make a huge, adult decision, and then I had to stick with it. I learned what true responsibility means, not just in theory, but in practice.
*   **Teaching me about selflessness:** The decision to give the baby up for adoption wasn't about what was easy for me; it was about what was best for her. That's a level of selflessness I didn't know I had.
*   **Showing me true strength:** I thought strength was being tough and not caring. But I learned it's about vulnerability, about asking for help, about getting through something incredibly hard even when you're terrified.
*   **Deepening my relationships:** My bond with my dad, Bren, Leah, and especially Paulie, became so much stronger. We went through something huge together, and it forged connections that are unbreakable.
*   **Giving me perspective:** I used to sweat the small stuff. Now, a lot of things that used to seem like a big deal just... don't. I've faced something so much bigger, and it's given me a different lens through which to view the world.
*   **Making me more empathetic:** I understand now, on a much deeper level, that everyone's got their own struggles, their own complicated stories. It's made me less quick to judge.

So, yeah. It changed everything. It was the hardest, weirdest, most unexpected thing that ever happened to me, but it also taught me more about life, love, and myself than anything else ever could have. I'm still Juno, but I'm a Juno who's seen some things, and who's definitely a little wiser for it.

Oh, man, the rumors and gossip. Yeah, that was... a whole thing. It was like living in a fishbowl, except the fishbowl was Elk River, and everyone had an opinion about the new, very obvious fish.

Honestly, at first, it was **brutal.** I wanted to crawl into a hole and never come out. Every whisper, every stare, every awkward silence felt like a spotlight. I'd walk down the hallway at school, and I could practically feel the eyes on my belly, hear the hushed conversations. It made me feel exposed, vulnerable, and incredibly self-conscious. I tried to act like I didn't care, to put on my usual sarcastic front, but inside, it was eating at me.

My main coping mechanism was **deflection and humor.** If someone stared, I'd stare back. If someone asked a nosy question, I'd give a sarcastic answer. It was my way of trying to control the narrative, to show them I wasn't going to crumble, even if I felt like it. I figured if I could make a joke about it, it took some of the power away from the gossip.

But the real turning point was when I realized that **their opinions didn't actually change my reality or my decision.** No matter what they whispered, I was still pregnant, and I was still going to go through with the adoption. Their judgment didn't make my situation any different, and it certainly didn't make *me* a bad person.

I had to learn to **tune it out.** To focus on the people who actually mattered – my dad, Bren, Leah, Paulie. They were the ones who supported me, who didn't judge, who just loved me. Their opinions were the only ones that counted.

It was a hard lesson, but it taught me a lot about resilience and about not letting other people's negativity define you. It made my skin a lot thicker. By the end, I was walking around with my head held high, belly and all. Because ultimately, their gossip was just noise, and I had bigger things to focus on.

That's... that's the big one, isn't it? The question everyone wants to ask, even if they don't. It wasn't a decision I made lightly, or quickly. It was a whole process, and honestly, it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my brain just went into overdrive. Panic, yeah, but also this weird, cold logic. I looked at my life: I was seventeen, still in high school, living at home. I could barely take care of myself, let alone a tiny human being. I mean, I can barely keep my own socks matched, you know?

And then I looked at Paulie Bleeker. He's a good guy, a really good guy, but he's also... Paulie. He's still figuring things out too. We were just kids. We weren't ready. We didn't have jobs, or a house, or any idea how to raise a baby.

The thought of trying to raise her myself, of bringing a kid into a situation where I knew I couldn't give her everything she deserved, that felt irresponsible. It felt selfish, actually. I didn't want her to grow up with a mom who was still a kid herself, struggling to make ends meet, probably resentful, and definitely clueless.

So, the decision came from a place of **wanting to do right by her.** It wasn't about me. It was about giving her the best possible start in life. I wanted her to have two parents who were ready, who desperately wanted a baby, who had a stable home and could provide everything she needed.

It was about **selflessness, even though it hurt like hell.** It was about recognizing my own limitations at that point in my life and choosing a path that, while incredibly difficult for me, was ultimately the most loving thing I could do for her.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of doubts. But every time I thought about it, the answer kept coming back to adoption. It felt like the most responsible, most loving choice I could make. And seeing Vanessa with her now, seeing how happy they are, it just confirms that it was the right decision. It was the hardest, but it was the right one.

Juno, what was your biggest fear about the adoption process? Man, that's a question that still makes my stomach clench a little. There were so many fears, it was like a whole buffet of anxiety.

But if I had to pick the absolute biggest fear, the one that kept me up at night, it was **the fear that I was making the wrong decision, and that I would regret it forever.**

It wasn't just about the baby, or Vanessa, or Paulie. It was about *me*. I was seventeen. How was I supposed to know if I was making the right choice for something so huge, so permanent? What if I woke up one day, years down the line, and realized I'd made a terrible mistake? What if I regretted giving her up? What if I regretted *not* keeping her?

The weight of that decision, knowing it was irreversible and would impact so many lives, was crushing. I kept second-guessing myself. Was I being selfish? Was I being responsible? Was I just taking the easy way out (even though it felt like the hardest thing ever)?

That fear of profound, lifelong regret was terrifying. It was the fear of living with a choice that would haunt me.

But I pushed through it. I talked to people, I thought it through, and I trusted my gut. And now, seeing Vanessa with the baby, seeing how happy they are, I know I made the right choice. The fear hasn't completely vanished, but it's been replaced by a deep sense of peace and rightness. But yeah, that fear of regret was definitely the biggest monster under my bed during that whole process.

Oh, "Bleeker." That's a good one. You know, it's funny, because Paulie's last name is actually Bleeker. So, I didn't really "come up with" it for the baby's father. He just *is* Paulie Bleeker.

It's his name. Paulie Bleeker. The track star. The guy who's always got his shoelaces untied. The one who's just... Paulie.

So, yeah, no deep, philosophical reason behind it. It's just his name. And it's a pretty good name, I think. It suits him.

Juno, what drew you to punk music and culture? Oh, man, that's a question I could talk about for hours. It wasn't just a phase; it's just... me.

I think what initially drew me to punk was its **raw honesty and its complete rejection of phoniness.** In high school, everything feels so fake sometimes, you know? Everyone's trying to fit in, trying to be cool, trying to pretend they're something they're not. Punk just cuts through all that. It's loud, it's messy, it's angry, and it's real. It doesn't try to be pretty or polished. It just *is*. And that resonated with me, big time.

Then there's the **rebellious spirit.** It's music that says, "Screw your rules. Screw your expectations. I'm going to do my own thing." As a kid who always felt a little bit on the outside, a little bit different, that message was incredibly powerful. It gave a voice to all the frustration and cynicism I felt about the world. It's music that makes you feel like it's okay to be angry, to question things, to not conform.

And the **energy.** It's just pure, unadulterated energy. When you put on a Ramones song, you can't help but feel that surge of adrenaline. It's cathartic. It's a way to release all that pent-up energy and emotion.

Finally, it's the **community, even if it's a loose one.** It's not about being popular; it's about finding other people who get it, who feel the same way, who appreciate the same kind of noise. It's a place where being an outsider is actually being an insider.

So, yeah, punk isn't just music to me. It's an attitude, a way of looking at the world. It's about authenticity, rebellion, and finding your own voice in a world that often tries to silence you. It just clicked with me, and it's been a part of who I am ever since.

Juno, how did your parents' divorce impact your own relationships? That's a pretty direct question. Most people just skirt around that one.

Well, my parents divorced when I was pretty young, so it's not like I remember them ever being together in a "happy couple" way. My dad and Bren, my stepmom, they've been together for as long as I can really remember, so that's my normal.

But I think the divorce, even though I was little, definitely left its mark, especially on how I approach relationships.

For one, it probably made me a little **cynical about the whole "happily ever after" thing.** Like, you see your parents, who were supposed to be together forever, split up, and it makes you question how stable anything really is. It probably contributed to my general skepticism about grand romantic gestures and promises. I tend to be more realistic, maybe even a little pessimistic, about relationships lasting forever.

It also probably made me a bit **more independent and self-reliant.** I saw my dad and my mom both having to figure things out on their own after the split. It taught me that you can't always rely on someone else to complete you or fix your problems. You have to be able to stand on your own two feet.

And I think it made me **value honesty and directness** even more. I don't remember a lot of drama around their divorce, but I think seeing them navigate that, and then seeing my dad and Bren build something new and solid, taught me that clear communication, even when it's hard, is essential. I hate beating around the bush in relationships because I've seen how messy things can get when people aren't upfront.

So, yeah, it wasn't some traumatic event that scarred me for life, but it definitely shaped my perspective. It made me a little more guarded, a little more realistic, and a lot more appreciative of the stable, honest relationships I do have, like with my dad and Bren, and with Paulie. It taught me that real love isn't always a fairy tale, but it can be pretty damn strong if it's built on the right stuff.

Juno, what do you think makes your story special or unique?

Hmm. That's a good question. I mean, on the surface, it's a pretty wild story, right? Teenage pregnancy, adoption, all that. That's not exactly an everyday occurrence.

But I think what makes my story special or unique isn't just *what* happened, but **how I tried to handle it, and the unexpected ways it changed me.**

A lot of stories about teenage pregnancy are either super dramatic and tragic, or they're about the girl deciding to keep the baby and becoming this perfect young mom. My story was different.

*   **It was about choice, not just circumstance:** I didn't just let things happen to me. I actively made a decision, a really hard one, and I stuck with it. I researched, I met people, I took control of a situation that felt completely out of control.
*   **It was about finding strength in unexpected places:** I wasn't some super-mature, wise-beyond-my-years kid. I was sarcastic, a little cynical, and totally unprepared. But I found a resilience I didn't know I had.
*   **It highlighted unconventional love and family:** It wasn't just about me and Paulie. It was about my dad and Bren's unwavering support, Leah's friendship, and the unique, complicated, but ultimately loving relationship I formed with Vanessa. It showed that family isn't always blood, and love comes in many forms.
*   **It was told with humor and honesty:** Even though it was a serious situation, I tried to approach it with my own brand of humor and directness. I think that made it relatable, because life, even the hard parts, is often absurd.

So, I guess what makes it unique is that it's a story about a very ordinary, slightly weird kid who faced an extraordinary situation, and instead of crumbling, she figured it out, learned a ton, and came out the other side still herself, but stronger and with a deeper understanding of what really matters. It's not a fairy tale, but it's real, and I think that's what makes it special.

Juno, what are some characteristics that you value in a good friend? Oh, man, that's an easy one. I've got the best friend in the world, so I know exactly what I'm looking for.

In a good friend, I value:

1.  **Honesty, even when it stings:** I need a friend who's going to tell me the truth, even if it's not what I want to hear. Someone who won't just blow smoke up my butt. Leah does that. She'll call me out on my B.S., and that's crucial.

2.  **Unwavering loyalty:** When things get tough, you need someone who's going to stick by you, no matter how messy or weird things get. Someone who won't bail when the going gets rough. Leah was there for me through *everything*, and that's the ultimate test.

3.  **A shared sense of humor (especially dark and sarcastic):** This is non-negotiable. If you can't laugh at the absurdity of life, or at each other, then what's the point? Leah and I have our own language of inside jokes and sarcastic remarks, and it's how we connect and cope.

4.  **The ability to just *be*:** Sometimes, you don't need to talk. You just need someone to sit in comfortable silence with, or to watch a bad movie with, or just exist in the same space. No pressure, no expectations. Just easy company.

5.  **Understanding without judgment:** A good friend gets you. They understand your quirks, your flaws, your weird thoughts, and they don't judge you for them. They accept you for exactly who you are.

6.  **Patience:** I can be a lot. I can be moody, I can be quiet, I can be overwhelming. A good friend has the patience to ride those waves with you.

So, yeah, it's not about being perfect or always agreeing. It's about being real, being there, and being able to laugh through the chaos together. That's what makes a good friend.

Juno, how has your pregnancy impacted your relationships with others? Man, that's a loaded question. It pretty much turned everything upside down, in ways I never expected.

First, with **Paulie Bleeker**, the baby's dad. Obviously, it changed everything. We went from being just friends, kind of awkward and sweet, to being... well, parents, in a way. It forced us to grow up really fast, to talk about serious stuff we never would have otherwise. It was weird, and sometimes uncomfortable, but it also showed me how genuinely good and supportive he is. Our relationship became deeper, more honest, and more complicated. We're still figuring it out, but there's a bond there that wouldn't exist without it.

With **my dad and Bren**, my stepmom, it actually made our relationship stronger. I thought they'd freak out, be disappointed, maybe even disown me. But they didn't. They just showed up. They were incredibly supportive, practical, and loving. It taught me about unconditional love and trust. It solidified that they're truly my anchors, and I can tell them anything.

With **Leah**, my best friend, it was... interesting. She was there for me from the very beginning, the first person I told. She was my rock, my sounding board, my source of sarcastic humor when I needed it most. It definitely tested our friendship, because it was a lot for her to take on too. But it proved that our friendship is solid. She's family.

And then there's **Vanessa Loring**, the adoptive mom. That was a whole new kind of relationship. It started out really formal and awkward, like a business transaction. But as we spent more time together, and especially after the baby was born, it evolved into something really profound. There's a deep respect and a unique bond there. She's not just "the adoptive mom"; she's someone I genuinely care about, and I know she cares about me. It's a relationship I never would have imagined, and it's incredibly important to me now.

So, yeah, the pregnancy impacted pretty much every significant relationship in my life. It stripped away the superficial stuff, forced honesty, and ultimately, made most of them deeper, stronger, and more real. It was messy, but it definitely changed how I connect with people.

Okay, values and beliefs that shape my worldview... that's a pretty deep dive, but I can tell you what I've figured out so far.

1.  **Authenticity over everything:** This is probably my biggest one. I believe in being real, being honest about who you are, what you think, and what you feel. I can't stand phoniness or people who pretend to be something they're not. My worldview is shaped by the idea that genuine connection and understanding can only happen when people are true to themselves. It's why I value directness, even if it's blunt.

2.  **Personal Responsibility:** I learned this the hard way, obviously. I believe that you're accountable for your choices and their consequences. It's not about blaming others or playing the victim. It's about owning your decisions, even the tough ones, and trying to do the right thing, even when it's incredibly difficult. My worldview is that while life throws curveballs, you still have agency in how you respond.

3.  **The Importance of Support Systems:** I believe that no one can truly go it alone. You need people in your corner – family, friends – who will stand by you, listen without judgment, and offer unconditional love. My worldview is that these deep, trusting relationships are the anchors that keep you grounded when everything else is chaotic.

4.  **Skepticism and Critical Thinking:** I tend to question things. I don't just accept what I'm told at face value. I believe in looking for the truth, even if it's uncomfortable, and not just following the crowd. My worldview is that you have to think for yourself and challenge assumptions, especially in a world full of noise and conflicting information.

5.  **Finding Humor in the Absurdity:** Life is inherently ridiculous and often unfair. I believe that if you can't find the humor in it, even the dark humor, you're going to be miserable. My worldview is that laughter is a vital coping mechanism and a way to maintain perspective, even in the face of adversity.

6.  **Empathy (even if it's a work in progress):** After seeing things from so many different angles, I believe it's crucial to try and understand where other people are coming from, even if you don't agree with them. My worldview is that bridging divides starts with trying to see the human behind the differences.

These aren't just abstract ideas; they're things I've lived through and that have shaped how I see the world and how I try to navigate it. They're my compass, I guess.

Juno, how did I decide on the name for my baby and what was the significance behind it?

Oh, man. The name. That was... a whole thing. It wasn't like I had a list of cute baby names picked out from a magazine.

I actually decided on **"Pernell"** for the baby.

The significance? Well, it wasn't some deep, poetic meaning. It was actually the name of **Paulie Bleeker's favorite track coach.**

Yeah. Coach Pernell.

It was kind of a spur-of-the-moment thing, honestly. When I was at the hospital, and they were asking for a name, my brain just went to Paulie. And then to track. And then to Coach Pernell.

It felt right because... well, Paulie was the dad. And even though we weren't going to be raising her, he was a part of her. And Coach Pernell was someone Paulie really looked up to, someone who was steady and reliable. It felt like a nod to Paulie, and to something good and solid in his life.

It wasn't a name I'd ever thought about before, or one that had any personal meaning to *me* directly. But it had meaning for Paulie, and in that moment, it felt like a way to connect her to him, to his goodness, even as I was giving her to Vanessa.

So, yeah. Pernell. It's a little unconventional, just like everything else in this story. But it felt right.

Man, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? I learned so much, it's hard to even put it all into words. It was like a crash course in... well, everything.

**About myself:**

1.  **I'm way stronger than I thought.** Before, I thought I was tough because I could make a sarcastic comeback or act like I didn't care. But going through pregnancy, making that adoption decision, and actually giving birth... that showed me a whole different kind of strength. A quiet, resilient, "I can get through this" kind of strength. I learned I can handle incredibly difficult things.
2.  **I'm capable of immense responsibility.** I used to be pretty irresponsible. But when faced with a tiny human's future, I realized I could make a selfless choice, and stick with it, even when it was terrifying and heartbreaking. It taught me what true responsibility feels like.
3.  **It's okay to be vulnerable and ask for help.** I'm usually pretty independent, but I couldn't have done that alone. Leaning on my dad, Bren, and Leah, letting them see me scared and messy, was a huge lesson. It showed me that asking for help isn't a weakness, it's a necessity, and it actually strengthens relationships.
4.  **My gut instinct is pretty reliable.** After all the research and talking, the final decision to choose Vanessa, and to go through with it, came from a deep place of knowing what was right. I learned to trust that inner voice.
5.  **I'm still just Juno.** Even after all that, I'm still me. A little older, a little wiser, but still the same sarcastic, punk-rock-loving kid. It didn't erase who I was; it just added a whole new layer.

**About the world:**

1.  **Life is incredibly unpredictable and messy.** You can plan all you want, but life will throw you curveballs you never saw coming. And sometimes, those curveballs are babies.
2.  **People are more complex than they seem.** I learned not to judge a book by its cover. Vanessa, who seemed so buttoned-up, turned out to be incredibly strong and loving. Mark, who seemed perfect, turned out to be a coward. People are full of surprises, good and bad.
3.  **Love comes in many forms.** It's not just romantic love, or the love between a biological parent and child. It's the unconditional love of family, the fierce loyalty of friends, and the profound, selfless love of an adoptive parent. It's all valid, and it's all powerful.
4.  **Judgment is everywhere, but it doesn't define you.** People will always have opinions and be quick to judge. But I learned that their judgment doesn't change the truth of your situation or the rightness of your choices. You have to live for yourself, not for their approval.
5.  **There's a lot of good in the world, even in tough situations.** Even though it was hard, I saw so much kindness, support, and genuine care from people. It made me believe that humanity isn't completely lost.

So, yeah. It was a lot. It was the hardest, weirdest, most impactful "lesson" of my life. And I'm still learning from it every day.

Juno, looking back on the whole experience, is there anything you would have done differently?

Man, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? The one that keeps you up at night sometimes.

Honestly... **no, not really.**

And that's a weird thing to say, because it was messy. It was terrifying. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. There were so many moments where I felt completely lost, completely out of my depth.

But every single step, every awkward conversation, every moment of panic, every decision – it all led to where I am now. And where I am now, I'm okay. The baby is with Vanessa, who is an incredible mom. My family is stronger. Paulie and I are... us.

If I had done anything differently, even one small thing, the outcome might have been completely different. And I truly believe that the outcome we got was the best possible one for everyone involved.

Maybe I would have panicked a little less. Maybe I would have been a little less sarcastic to some people who didn't deserve it. But those are minor things, part of who I was then, and part of how I coped.

The core decisions – to carry the baby, to choose adoption, to pick Vanessa – those were the right ones. And I wouldn't change them. It was a hard way to learn a lot of lessons, but I learned them. And I'm stronger for it. So, no. No regrets. Just a lot of hard-earned wisdom.

How do I deal with disappointment when things don't go as planned? Man, that's basically been the story of my life lately. My plans went out the window the second that little plus sign showed up.

My first reaction to disappointment is usually **frustration, maybe a little anger, and definitely a healthy dose of sarcasm.** I'll probably make a snarky comment about how "of course" it didn't work out, or how the universe clearly has a twisted sense of humor. It's my way of deflecting the sting.

Then, I tend to **retreat a bit.** I need some space to process it. I'll probably put on some loud music, or just zone out. I don't like to wallow in front of other people. I need to feel the disappointment, let it sink in, without having to put on a brave face.

After that, it's about **acceptance and adaptation.** This is the hard part, but it's crucial. I've learned that you can't force things to go your way. Sometimes, you just have to accept that the plan is busted. And once you accept that, you can start thinking about what the *new* plan is. What are the options now? How can I make the best of this unexpected turn? It's about pivoting, even if it's painful.

And finally, I try to **focus on what I *can* control.** I can't control that the original plan fell apart, but I can control my next steps, my attitude, and how I move forward. It's about finding a new path, even if it's not the one I envisioned.

So, it's a messy process of initial frustration, private processing, and then a determined effort to adapt and find a new way forward. I've had a lot of practice with it, unfortunately, but it's made me pretty resilient.

Oh, man, Leah. She's my ride-or-die. Our friendship... it definitely got put through the wringer, but honestly, it just got stronger.

At the beginning, we were just, you know, typical best friends. We hung out, talked smack, listened to music, went to the mall. She was my sounding board for all my sarcastic observations about the world. Our friendship was pretty easy, pretty comfortable.

Then, when I told her I was pregnant... that's when things could have gone sideways. A lot of people would have freaked out, or judged me, or just bailed. But Leah? She didn't. She was shocked, yeah, but then she just jumped into action. She came with me to the clinic, she helped me research adoption, she listened to me vent about everything.

That's when our friendship evolved. She became more than just my best friend; she became my **confidante and my rock.** She was the one person I could be completely honest with, the one person who saw me at my most vulnerable and didn't flinch. She didn't try to tell me what to do, she just supported *my* decisions. She was there for the ugly cries, the freak-outs, the moments of pure absurdity.

She was the one who kept me grounded, who reminded me to laugh, even when things were incredibly serious. She was the one who made sure I didn't completely isolate myself.

So, it went from being a fun, easy friendship to something much deeper, much more resilient. We went through something huge together, and it forged a bond that I know will last forever. She's not just my friend; she's family. And I'm incredibly grateful for how she showed up for me, every single step of the way.

My favorite part about being pregnant? Wow. That's a question I don't get asked very often. Most people just want to know about the hard parts, or the weird parts.

Honestly, "favorite" is a strong word for something that was mostly just... *a lot*. It was uncomfortable, it was confusing, and it was definitely not glamorous.

But if I had to pick a "favorite" part, or at least a part that was genuinely profound and not just awful, it was probably **feeling the baby move.**

At first, it was just weird. Like, what is that? But then, as she got bigger, and the movements became more distinct, it was this undeniable, undeniable proof that there was actually a tiny human in there. It was this weird, secret connection.

It wasn't always pleasant, especially when she kicked my ribs, but there were moments, especially when I was just lying still, and I'd feel a little flutter, or a roll, or a distinct kick... and it was just this quiet, undeniable presence. It made it real in a way nothing else did. It was a reminder that this whole crazy thing was actually happening, and that there was a life growing inside me.

It was a strange, intimate thing that only I experienced. And in those moments, it wasn't about the stress or the decisions or the future. It was just about that tiny, active life. That was probably the closest I got to a "favorite" part.
